awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Culture of Marine Protozoans Using Industrial Bioreactors
awd_abstract_narration:
Diseases caused by intracellular parasites pose some unique challenges due to the complex life cycle of these organisms and difficulty in obtaining sufficient quantities of protein source material. Conventional expression systems can address some of these challenges but in a limited way, and larger proteins are particularly difficult to produce using conventional bacterial, yeast, or animal cell systems. This project, which uses a marine protozoan parasite that infects oysters, is aimed to optimize the growth of this protozoan in large volumes and to domesticate it to produce large amounts of the proteins needed for vaccine validation, drug screening, and industrial processes. The project is expected to provide new insights on how to improve the yield of proteins at industrially-relevant scale using a marine protozoan, and could generate potentially transformative tools for use in the study and production of proteins difficult to express in other systems. The project research activity will be carried out at Bigelow Laboratory and the University of Maine, and integrated into the biotechnology curriculum at Southern Maine Community College, encouraging students in the formation and testing of hypotheses regarding media composition, growth parameters, and purification strategies. This approach will strengthen and expand the technical and intellectual abilities of the students and further prepare them for continuing their education or participation in the STEM workforce.

The study of proteins from intracellular parasites poses some unique challenges due to the complex life cycle of these organisms and difficulty in obtaining sufficient quantities of source material. Conventional expression systems can address some of these challenges but in a limited way. This project seeks to develop and validate a heterologous protein expression system based not on the conventional systems, but on the marine protozoan Perkinsus marinus. The project is intended to scale up expression protocols from tissue culture flasks to multiliter scale industrially-relevant bioreactors. The effects of temperature, aeration, agitation, salinity, pH, and nutrient formulation on growth and protein production and recovery will be examined using process-controlled bioreactors. Also, two bioreactor operational modes, batch, and fed-batch will be tested. The multiple Perkinsus spp. and strains will be compared to determine spp./strain suitability/performance depending on the gene/protein targeted. Transcriptomics and promoter-trap mutagenesis will be used to develop the suite of transfection vectors (e.g. secretion, organelle targeting, inducible and constitutive) and tools (e.g. CRISPR/Cas9) that would facilitate the large-scale production of the protein of interest. The project is also intended to develop large-scale purification schemes for recombinant proteins produced in P. marinus including an assessment of various purification tags for use in affinity chromatographic separation. This research could revolutionize the development of oral vaccines. It will also facilitate much deeper characterization of protozoans than has been previously possible. The expression of large proteins is problematic, and this technology could enhance capabilities to correctly express large amounts of such protein.

por.por_cntn:
Raw oysters are a popular choice among seafood lovers. Once limited to vacation trips to the beach; now, they are available anywhere in the country. Over the past several decades, research on oysters has focused on improving production, managing resources, and pursuing basic questions regarding biology and ecology. One of the main foci of my laboratory is to understand how diseases affect oysters. Like any living organism, oysters are attacked by viruses, bacteria, and protozoans, all of which are disease agents. We are particularly interested in 'Dermo' disease in oysters caused by the protozoan parasite Perkinsus marinus. One of the advantages of working with this lovely parasite is that we can grow it independently in the lab without a need for the host, and it is not pathogenic to humans. We can trick the parasite into propagation without the oyster, a rare phenomenon in the parasitology world, providing a rich culture medium. Perkinsus marinus genome codes for more genes than the human genome does. Confronted with the challenge of understanding this parasite, we have been developing the tools to interrogate the genome and domesticate it. There is an increasing need to study the proteins the genes code for in the exponentially growing genome databases. We rely on expressing those genes on a surrogate organism like bacteria or baker's yeast. Unfortunately, moving from gene to protein is not straightforward; the gene we want to express is from a distant relative, and the surrogate organism does not like it, or the protein is inactive. In this project, we are developing the tools and protocols to test P. marinus as a surrogate organism for the expression of genes. We initially focused on genes from other parasites (e.g., malaria, toxoplasmosis); the rationale was that a parasite is most like to express genes from another parasite, especially if they are close relatives. Indeed, P. marinus  was able to express those genes.

The next step was to produce the protein in large amounts by moving the parasite from cultures in small flasks to bioreactors to culture it in liters. During prior research, we demonstrated that humanized mice fed with P. marinus do not develop histopathology but elicit specific immunity to the oyster parasite. When the pandemic hit us, we wanted to contribute to the fight against it, so we focused on expressing the SARS-CoV-2 Spike gene in P. marinus. We succeeded. To accelerate the introduction of genes into P. marinus, we developed the CRISPR/Cas9 system. By carefully targeting the genome, we would be in the future able to express vaccine candidate genes for later testing if the cocktail of viral genes provides protection against COVID-19 and help to terminate this 21st-century pest. The success of this platform would result in new systems to explore vaccine development outside of the traditional approaches.

Perkinsus marinus has also been an excellent tool for teaching students genetic engineering. We were lucky to introduce high schoolers, undergraduate and graduate students to work with this fascinating marine organism. Together we are working to give a good name to a parasite by using it to understand basic cell biology and making it a surrogate organism to produce proteins of medical and veterinary relevance.
